item.title: Lojban
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
mi zu vu zasti

That phrase is Lojban for "A long time before or from now, far away, I exist."

Lojban is a language newly designed by a scientific committee. It is a language that the pointy-eared, green-blooded Vulcan, Mr. Spock, would love because it is based on the principles of predicate logic, which, however, does not imply that it cannot be emotional; in fact, it has a wide range of words to express emotions. Lojban is a cool, exotic, postmodern, widely expressive language. It would appeal to philosophers, computer scientists, and technophiles. Lojban is beautiful in its own logical way...

Lojban is culturally neutral. Much of its vocabulary is based on the six most spoken languages in the world: Chinese, English, Hindi, Spanish, Russian, and Arabic; generated words were selected by a computer algorithm.

Lojban grammar is nothing like that found in natural languages. It is really outlandish. For one thing, tense is optional. Due to its simple, unambiguously structured grammar, Lojban can be easily parsed by computers, so that it can be used in the future for computer-human interaction. Similar in structure to existing artificial intelligence (AI) programming languages, Lojban will likely be a most powerful tool in AI research.

Lojban was originally designed to research the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, which is based on the principles of Linguistic Determinism and Linguistic Relativity. Linguistic Determinism is the idea that the language we use to some degree determines the way in which we view and think about the universe. Linguistic Relativity states that distinctions encoded in one language are unique to that language alone, and that there is no limit to the structural diversity of languages. So basically, the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis is the idea that our perceptions and distinctions about the universe come from our language.

Thus one can surmise that Lojban is a mind-altering language. Your perceptions may change with its use. Although Lojban has its origins among avid technocrats, it has a high degree of artistic leeway, which of course is limited only by one's own creativity.

So instead of playing chess or doing crossword puzzles, you can practice mental yoga with Lojban!

.e'osai ko sarji la lojban.
Please support Lojban!

item.title: The Word "lo" in Lojban (1994)
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
To: lojban@cuvmb.cc.columbia.edu
Subject: lo [nonexistent]
From: Logical Language Group <lojbab>
Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 00:50:41 -0400
Cc: lojbab@access.digex.net

----------------------------------------
----------------------------------------

>From: ucleaar <ucleaar@ucl.ac.uk>
>> JL>> If they are the same, the statement "lo [unicorn] cu brode"
>> JL>>    should be false, since noda cu [unicorn].
>> JL>
>> JL>If no unicorns exist in the world where the statement is used, then the
>> JL>statement is false in that world, yes.
>> 
>> 1. Therefore the statement "Elves have pointed ears" is false since
>> there is no such thing as an elf.  Likewise definitional statements
>> "Elves are humanoid" is also false even if definitional.  How can you
>> describe the properties of a hypothetical but non-existent object if any
>> statement about such an object is false.
>
>But your examples would translate as "ro elf" or "lohe elf", not as
>"lo elf".
>
>We need different examples where we want to discuss hypothetical
>but nonexistent objects using "lo".

I can't say for sure about "lo'e", but this does not work for "ro elf".
If the statement "ro [elf] cu [has pointed ears]" is true, then so is
"ro [elf] cu [has unpointed ears]" and "ro [elf] na [has pointed ears]".

Whether "lo'e" makes any meaningful claims is really unclear, especially
if it is a claim about nonexistent objects.  I mean:  if elves do not
exist, what can you say about a typical elf?  Now, a stereotypical one
(le'e), maybe.  Of course "the typical family" has 1.5 kids in the USA
these days by one epistemology (statistics) so it doesn't really exist.

The crux of the current definition of lo allowing nonexistent referents.
Try to fill the x1 place of "na'e zasti" (nalzasti) without such a way
to talk about nonexistent referents.  The method must be one such that
it is not equally true that "ko'a" zasti gi'e nalzasti is not also true
(since "ro [elves]" should have the same truth value no matter what the
predicate, it just doesn't solve the problem.

Another posting - re default quantifiers for "lo"
>You're right:  such has been the stipulation.  But what is the
>rationale?  What is the interpretation for uncountable stuff?  "At least
>one water"?

The mass/count noun distinction is not a language universal.  I have
been given to understand that where there is a distinction, there isn't
universal agreement on which concepts are mass and which are count.

We tried in Lojban to beg the question, but in this case, we may be
running into a difficult-to-bypass English bias.  We aren't used to
thinking of 'water' as a countable noun.

The wording of the place structure/definition tries to hint at a
solution, but as an English speaker, I may have failed in the attempt.
It says x1 is a portion/quantity of water.  What constitutes a 'portion'
may be context dependent.

With "gravel" it becomes easier - we have the mass version "gravel", and
we have "a piece of gravel".  With water, the portion size could be
"a drop of water", "a glass of water", etc.  There is also the count/mass
noun person/people.

BTW, the quantifier "su'o" means "at least 'some'", but with 'some'
possibly being singular (i.e. 1).  Thus, on "lo" it generally means "at
least one".  But on a normally English mass noun, "at least some" is
more accurate, since the size of the arbitrary portion chosen to be a
unit can be as small as necessary to veridically be water (i.e. perhaps
close to the molecular level).  But if the context has units of water
being glasses, "lo djacu" can (probably) be less than a unit/glass of
water, say half of a glass.  (I'll accept counter argument on this one).

lojbab

item.title: Lojban's Completion (1997)
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
From: Logical Language Group (lojbab@access5.digex.net)
Subject: ANNOUNCE: Design Completion for Artificial Language Loglan/Lojban 
This is the only article in this thread  
View: Original Format 
Newsgroups: sci.lang, alt.language.artificial, comp.ai.nat-lang, alt.uu.lang.misc, misc.education
Date: 1997/01/10 
 

This announcement is posted to various newsgroups because of the
potential specific applications of the Loglan/Lojban language to the
subject of these newsgroups.

                          ANNOUNCEMENT
                    by Robert LeChevalier
         President of The Logical Language Group, Inc.

On behalf of the Logical Language Group, Inc.  (LLG), I am pleased to
announce a major milestone in the 42-year-old Loglan Project.

LLG has now baselined and published electronically a complete reference
grammar of the artificial language called at various times "Loglan-88",
"Loglan", "Loglan/Lojban", "Lojban - A Realization of Loglan", and
perhaps most commonly "Lojban" alone.

From the standpoint of LLG, THE LOGLAN/LOJBAN LANGUAGE DESIGN is
considered COMPLETE upon this baseline.  We now enter into the usage
phase, and eventually the linguistic research and application phases of
the project.

We welcome all readers of this announcement to investigate
Loglan/Lojban, to consider/discuss possible applications.  Identified
possible applications include linguistics and artificial intelligence
research, research and teaching in logic, linguistics, and
second/foreign language education, use as an intermediate language for
machine-translation and archival of text, and as an international
language.  There have been other suggestions of applications in
psychology and computer science.

In addition to practical applications, Loglan/Lojban has proven to be an
outstanding "mind-stretching" exercise that teaches users about their
own language, while allowing them to play creatively with new concepts.

Taken from our introductory brochure, available in full on our FTP and
WWW sites (see below), the following states some primary features of the
Loglan/Lojban language:

   o   Lojban is designed to be used by people in communication with each
           other, and possibly in the future with computers.
   o   Lojban is designed to be culturally neutral.
   o   Lojban grammar is based on the principles of logic.
   o   Lojban has an unambiguous grammar.
   o   Lojban has phonetic spelling, and unambiguous resolution of sounds
           into words.
   o   Lojban is simple compared to natural languages; it is easy to
           learn.
   o   Lojban's 1300 root words can be easily combined to form a
           vocabulary of millions of words.
   o   Lojban is regular; the rules of the language are without
           exception.
   o   Lojban attempts to remove restrictions on creative and clear
           thought and communication.
   o   Lojban has a variety of uses, ranging from the creative to the
           scientific, from the theoretical to the practical.

A small core of people have demonstrated extensive conversational
ability in the language, and a much larger group has written in or
translated text into Lojban.  Much of this substantial volume of text is
available in archives on our electronic sites.  The base of skilled
Lojbanists is international, with representatives from Australia, the
UK, Finland, Bulgaria, Croatia, and Argentina, as well as several from
the US, counted among the most skilled.  There is Lojban "conversation"
as well as discussion of the language (in both English and Lojban) on a
Listserv mailing list (see below for subscription information).

For historical and other reasons we continue to assert our role as a
continuation of the "Loglan Project" started by Dr. James Cooke Brown
in 1954, and documented among other places in the June 1960 "Scientific
American" article entitled "Loglan".  That article stated the primary
design goals of the language and reasons why the language effort would
be useful.  In developing Loglan/Lojban we have striven to remain true
to those design goals, and indeed believe that we have succeeded in
fulfilling them to an extent far greater than Dr. Brown conceived
possible.  We continue to use the name "Loglan" with pride, honoring
Dr. Brown's seminal ideas.

We regret that Dr. Brown insisted on restrictive claims for control
over distribution and use of his earlier versions of Loglan, including a
full copyright on the language and its vocabulary.  Those claims led the
community of Loglan users to unite as the Logical Language Group to
redevelop a public domain version of the Loglan language, a process that
has taken nearly 10 years and culminates in this announcement.  This
version of the language is intended to supersede the previous incomplete
and restricted-usage versions of the language promulgated by Dr. Brown.

With the approval of the Board of Directors of LLG, as of 0000 GMT on 10
January 1997, the Lojban language design is baselined and frozen for a
minimum period in excess of 5 years.  We intend that during this period
a community of skilled Loglan/Lojban speakers will develop to the point
that the role of the organization will be one of documenting, educating
and researching the actual use of the language, rather than the
prescribing of a language design.

By this act, we make it clear that Loglan/Lojban has ceased to be a
"language development project", and instead is now a "language" proper.
This transition is vital, since of hundreds or even thousands of
artificial language projects, only a few have achieved a stability that
has allowed large numbers of people to learn the language.  Among
artificial languages, only Esperanto and Gode's Interlingua have
achieved stability and a solid base of language speakers on a long term
basis; other artificial languages continued to be changed by reformers
and lost the few speakers who had started to learn the language.  We
intend that Loglan/Lojban achieve stability and a large international
speaking-community, comparable with these relatively stable and
successful languages.  Potential Lojban students who have waited for a
stable language have LLG's formal commitment towards that stability.

The completed Loglan/Lojban design has been documented in the form of a
reference grammar, various word lists, a formal grammar processible by
the computer parser tool "YACC", and various other teaching materials
and material actually written in the language.  These documents make
Lojban what is probably one of the most thoroughly described of human
languages.

The reference grammar, just completed and published electronically with
HTML coding on the World Wide Web (WWW) will also be published in
hardbound within 2-3 months.  LLG is accepting notification requests
from those with possible interest in purchasing the book when it is
printed.

The completed language design is being turned over to the budding
community of Loglan/Lojban speakers and writers for their use and/or
application in any way they see fit.  The language and language design
and certain vital language design documents are being placed irrevocably
in the public domain, allowing speakers to use the language for whatever
purposes without legal constraint or obligation.

Text written to describe the language design, such as the reference
grammar, is being published electronically (and generally in print as
well), and is copyright under a liberal license that encourages
distribution and translation into other languages.  Chapter 21 of the
reference grammar contains the formal YACC grammar of the language and
is explicitly and irrevocably placed in the public domain.

The following paragraphs provide more detail on the nature of the
baseline, and the completion of the reference grammar that made the
baseline possible.

Acknowledgment of all who have contributed over the years to this effort
is impossible.  Hundreds of people have contributed to the technical
design of the language, and hundreds more have aided us with commentary
and financial support.  We make particular acknowledgment to Dr. James
Cooke Brown as inventor of the Loglan Project and the language, to Dr.
John (Parks-)Clifford, logician and linguist who has guided the most
sophisticated portions of the design, to John Cowan, Nick Nicholas, Bob
LeChevalier, Nora Tansky LeChevalier for long-term extended support of
the design and documentation efforts, to Athelstan, Ivan Derzhanski,
Colin Fine, Goran Topic, Sylvia Rutiser, and Jorge Llambias among many
others, for pioneering use of the language, to Jerry Altzman and Eric
Raymond for making the Lojban mailing list possible, to Veijo Vilva for
outstanding development and support of the Lojban WWW site, to Gary
Burgess, Tommy Whitlock, Jeff Taylor, and Jeff Prothero for critical
early design contributions that made the Lojban redevelopment of the
language possible, to John Hodges, Bob Chassell, the late Art Wieners,
and a multitude of others, for financial support and efforts in
promulgating the language widely.  I apologize to the many additional
deserved people, unmentioned above, who made this achievement possible.


REFERENCE GRAMMAR STATUS

The final draft of the Lojban Reference Grammar, authored by John Cowan
(cowan@ccil.org) has been placed on the Lojban FTP site, at the URL
listed below.  A copy will be available shortly after this announcement
on the Lojban WWW page, and we invite others with language and
linguistics pages to add links pointing to (or make copies of) this
document and the Lojban language resources.  The FTP site will be the
authoritative location for the baseline documents.

The text has been turned into HTML format for easier viewing with
HTML/WWW browsers and viewers.  (Accurate viewing will require an HTML
browser that responds to font directives, and will also require the SIL
IPA fonts and the Symbol font set for correct viewing of non-ASCII
symbols including the IPA symbols for the pronunciation guides.)

There may still be errors in example number reference:  specifically,
the reference may be to the wrong example number.  John Cowan welcomes
notification of such problems, as well as typos and any other severe
errors at his address (cowan@ccil.org) or via the LLG address below.

The baselined form of the reference grammar is the HTML format version
posted at the time that the baseline took effect.  With the baseline in
effect, only typos, HTML conversion errors, and other severe errors that
cause reader confusion which may be identified during the printed book
production phase will justify changes to the document.  Such changes
will be individually documented and made public as a formal change.

We intend that there be no technical changes to the baseline documents
during the freeze period.


LEXICON STATUS AND BASELINE

While the Lojban language design is considered complete, the Lojban
dictionary has not been completed.  As a result, the existing lexicon
(consisting of the gismu (root words), cmavo (structure words), rafsi
(root affixes for compounding) assignments, and some lujvo (compound
words)) is only loosely covered by this baseline.  Preliminary forms of
each segment of the dictionary are available electronically (via our FTP
and WWW sites), making a design baseline feasible and meaningful at this
time.

The final baseline of the lexicon, and electronic publication of the
dictionary is scheduled for 30 June 1997, approximately 6 months from
now.  Lexical items used in the reference grammar are of course frozen
by the current publication and baselining of that document.

The major purposes for the 6 month delay are

- to provide an opportunity to verify the dictionary text for
consistency with the rest of the baseline;

- to standardize and clarify incomplete definitions of cmavo and lujvo.

The amount of documentation change and editing required to complete the
dictionary, which is the baseline description document for the Lojban
lexicon covered therein, requires that we not call that document "final"
at this time.  The 6 month delay was therefore approved by the
membership of LLG voting at LogFest (our annual meeting) last summer.


5 YEAR MINIMUM DESIGN FREEZE

Following the lexicon baseline, the entire Lojban Language design will
not only be complete, but the language definition will be frozen for a
minimum period of 5 years, during which period LLG commits itself not to
consider ANY change proposals for the language.


DEFINITION OF "BASELINE" AND "FREEZE"

By using the terms "baseline" and "frozen", LLG is stating that during
the minimum 5 year period, it will be committed to supporting the
language status quo, and will neither propose nor make any changes to
the language design as an organization.

LLG will actively seek to expand the Lojban user community, and will
encourage that community to actively use the language.  That use will
likely result in enormous growth of the lexicon using the highly
productive methods designed into the language.  In addition, usage may
resolve hitherto undecided issues, and may bring to light and resolve
other issues not yet identified.  This growth and evolution will take
place informally, and without any restraints from LLG, in the manner of
natural language evolution.

Presuming that an active community forms, further language evolution
will NOT take place by prescriptive changes produced by the Lojban
designers.  The language freeze will then last indefinitely beyond the
five year minimum period.

LLG's long-term role will be to promote the language and to serve a
research and description function in analyzing how Lojban speakers
actually use the language.


ALL UNRESOLVED ISSUES TO BE RESOLVED BY ACTUAL USAGE

Design points not covered in the reference grammar and/or the dictionary
are intended to be resolved by actual usage, preferably by skilled
speakers of the language.  LLG may report on such usage when questions
arise, but will not rule prescriptively on whether the usage is
"correct" or not.  If a usage occurs in natural communication and it is
comprehended and accepted by other Lojbanists, then the usage is de
facto "valid".

Some Lojban supporters have asked that LLG make specific plans for a
language review following the 5 year period, that it establish a
committee and/or plan a formal procedure for proposing and discussing
proposals during that period for consideration and implementation
following the period.  The LLG Board of Directors believes that this is
contrary to the intended purpose of the baseline and freeze, which is to
turn over the language to the users of the language, and to remove LLG
from ANY prescriptive role which constrains the natural evolution of the
language.

LLG makes the commitment, however, that should it ever decide to
establish any such procedures after the 5 year period, that all
discussions of possible changes will occur solely in the Lojban
language, ensuring that only actual users of Lojban will participate in
any decision process.

Editors of publications sponsored by LLG shall have their own discretion
to accept or reject or edit Lojban text according to their own criteria,
which may include conformance with the language prescription.  If they
do so, however, their decisions will be personal, as individual
Lojbanists using the language, and based on their own competence in the
language.  Editors shall not prescribe language usage on behalf of LLG.
Similarly, members and officers of LLG (including myself) who are
actively speaking and using the language, may express opinions about
Lojban text and issues, but shall do so as Lojban users independent of
their LLG roles.


EXPERIMENTAL USAGES

The Lojban design includes language space specifically for trying new
ideas in language usage.  All cmavo (structure-words) of the form "xVV"
are formally undefined, as are all cmavo-form words formed by adding one
or more apostrophe and additional vowels onto the currently-used forms
VV and CVV.  There is also an untested concept for a specific subset of
6 letter fu'ivla (borrowing) space to be used as experimental "fu'ivla
gismu"; these would have the ability to be compounded into lujvo
(compounds).  The lujvo of course would also be experimental.

These experimental word forms may be freely used to experiment with new
usages in actual communication.  We intend (but will not enforce) that
the "xVV" cmavo space be permanently experimental, meaning that if
Lojban users wish to adopt an experimental usage that has been found
workable, we urge that they choose a cmavo from the longer undefined
cmavo space for permanent usage.  The very small number of undefined
cmavo in the regular cmavo space could also be used, but we urge that
they be reserved only for the most useful, widely accepted, and
frequently used new ideas.

Likewise, user additions to the regular 5-letter gismu forms are
discouraged but no ban will be enforced.  LLG intends to independently
verify any user-added gismu for consistency with the existing
prescription, and will document deviations descriptively, but will not
suggest or enforce alterations.

Lojban allows for unrestricted creation of lujvo compounds and fu'ivla
borrowings in accordance with rules and conventions discussed in the
reference grammar.  Users are encouraged to coin new words in these
forms as needed in speech and writing.

LLG intends to document new lujvo and fu'ivla that come into use.
Consistency or conflict with the lujvo-place structure conventions may
be analyzed, but LLG will not suggest or enforce alteration to match the
conventions.  Recognizing that Type IV fu'ivla are difficult to make
with assurance of validity, LLG intends to provide a service to
Lojbanists who wish to verify that a proposed word follows the
prescription.  Individual Lojbanists providing this service on behalf of
LLG may suggest alterations, but LLG as an organization will not enforce
any changes.

People using Lojban are encouraged to send archives of texts to the LLG
address below.  This will allow research analysis and documentation of
Lojban usages in the text.  Labelling the text "nopublic" or "not for
public archive" will restrict the text to archives that will be
available only to bona fide researchers.


ELECTRONIC PUBLISHING INFORMATION


The LLG e-mail address is:

lojbab@access.digex.net


The Lojban reference grammar and other documents are available at:

ftp://ftp.access.digex.net/pub/access/lojbab/


The Lojban WWW page is located at:

http://xiron.pc.helsinki.fi/lojban/


To subscribe to Lojban List, send:

subscribe lojban firstname lastname

to:

listserv@cuvmb.cc.columbia.edu

(You will get instruction on how to post when you subscribe.  If volume
on the list is too high for you, or you decide you are not interested,
please unsubscribe by sending "unsubscribe lojban" to the above
address.)

----
lojbab                                                lojbab@access.digex.net
Bob LeChevalier, President, The Logical Language Group, Inc.
2904 Beau Lane, Fairfax VA 22031-1303 USA                        703-385-0273
Artificial language Loglan/Lojban: ftp.access.digex.net /pub/access/lojbab
    or see Lojban WWW Server: href="http://xiron.pc.helsinki.fi/lojban/"

item.title: Volapkadom | Volapk House
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
'Twas an incredible story. One night in Germany in March of 1879, Father Johann Martin Schleyer (1831-1912) supposedly received a message from God, instructing him not to despair, and to create a new language that everyone in the world could speak. A year later, he published Volapk or "world-speech." 'Twas the first constructed language to encounter widespread interest and success. In its heyday, this invention claimed some 283 Volapk clubs, 316 textbooks, and 25-35 periodicals. But by the 1890's, the fad had waned due to politics whilst a new constructed language, Esperanto, soon eclipsed Volapk . There had been a Volapk revival after Arie de Jong's revisions of the language in 1921-31 (Volapk II). In any case, Volapk is a work of art that is worth a look even though very few people speak it today. Seeing full text in Volapk reminds one of German, but even more so, of Turkish! (The sign says "Menad bal pk bal" which means "One humanity, one language.")

Volapk binon jnik!

Volapk is beautiful!

item.title: Tagalog Orthographic Update Draft Proposal, Version 2
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
by Viktor Medrano

Tagalog, or "Filipino" as it is now known politically, is undergoing phonological evolution.  For instance, 'tiyn' (stomach) most often sounds like 'chan', 'diyn' (there) sounds like 'jan', and 'siy' (s/he) sounds like 'sha'.

I propose that the letter 'c' sound like 'ch' in 'champion' and the letter 'x' sound like 'sh' in 'shampoo'.  The letter 'j' should be used when there is a sound like 'j' in 'jump'.  When an 'i' is no longer pronounced, then it should not be written:  'niy' to 'nya'.  When a 'u' is no longer pronounced, then it should not be written:  'puwede' to 'pwede'.  When an 'a' tends to sound like an 'e', then it should be written as an 'e':  'may' to 'mey'.  More generally, spelling should reflect actual pronunciation:  'myroon' to 'meron'.

It is so common nowadays to code-switch between Tagalog and English, resulting in 'Taglish'.  I propose a new punctuation called the 'code-switch marker' in the form of a colon : and marks the transition between words and phrases of the different languages.  In this way, Taglish can be used in higher literature in a more structured format.

We can compare...

Old way--  "Ano'ng ginagawa niya diyan?  Kumukulog na yata ang tiyan niya.  Dapat kumain na siya.  May field trip siya bukas.  Anyway, call me tomorrow para puwede tayong mag-meeting."

New way--  "Ano'ng ginagawa nya jan?  Kumukulog na yata ang can nya.  Dapat kumain na xa.  Mey : field trip : xa bukas.  : Anyway, call me tomorrow : para pwede tayong mag:meeting."

English--  "What is he doing there?  His stomach is probably rumbling.  He should eat already.  He has a field trip tomorrow.  Anyway, call me tomorrow so we can have a meeting."

It is still, however, optimal to use accents in Tagalog text...

Well, that's my short proposal, at its second revision, for now.

item.title: Tagalog Orthographic Update Draft Proposal, Version 1
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
by Viktor Medrano

Tagalog, or "Filipino" as it is now known politically, is undergoing phonological evolution.  For instance, 'tiyn' (stomach) most often sounds like 'chan', 'diyn' sounds like 'jan', and 'siy' sounds like 'sha'.

I propose that the letter 'c' sound like 'ch' in 'champion' and the letter 'x' sound like 'sh' in 'shampoo'.  The letter 'j' should be used when there is a sound like 'j' in 'jump'.  When an 'i' is no longer pronounced, then it should not be written:  'niy' to 'nya'.  When a 'u' is no longer pronounced, then it should not be written:  'puwede' to 'pwede'.  When an 'a' tends to sound like an 'e', then it should be written as an 'e':  'may' to 'mey'.  More generally, spelling should reflect actual pronunciation:  'myroon' to 'meron'.

It is so common nowadays to code-switch between Tagalog and English, the resulting 'Taglish'.  I propose a new punctuation called the 'code-switch marker' which looks like two colons :: and marks the transition between words and phrases of the different languages.

We can compare...

Old way:  "Ano'ng ginagawa niya diyan?  Kumukulog na yata ang tiyan niya.  Dapat kumain na siya.  May field trip siya bukas.  Anyway, call me tomorrow para puwede tayong mag-meeting."

New way:  "Ano'ng ginagawa nya jan?  Kumukulog na yata ang can nya.  Dapat kumain na xa.  Mey :: field trip :: xa bukas.  :: Anyway, call me tomorrow :: para pwede tayong mag::meeting."

English:  "What is he doing there?  His stomach is probably rumbling.  He should eat already.  He has a field trip tomorrow.  Anyway, call me tomorrow so we can have a meeting."

It is still, however, optimal to use accents with Tagalog text...

Well, that's my short proposal for now.

item.title: My Tagalog Spiel
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
[tl][en]


"Hind kaalamn kund imahinasyn
ang tunay na sagisag ng intelihnsiy"
ang sabi ni Albert Einstein.

My Spiel

Tagalog is my native tongue from a land of coconut trees and woven baskets, the Philippines. There are lots of resources nowadays to learn it. See below the section on Recommended Resources for good dictionaries.

A good guideline on orthography and grammar is given in Apendiks V or page 167 of [ATIE] in Tagalog. It tells of how to aesthetically spell words borrowed from Spanish and English. Examples:

kongklusyon
konggresman
iskwad
nyutral
blakbord
drayber
detatsment
tsekpoynt
pridyider
satelayt
anawnser
etc.

In the Wish List are also books for sale available online; it is not meant to be an exhaustive list and I will update this once in a while.

My Notes

I wrote a history and grammar description of Tagalog using Esperanto as the metalanguage. If you can read Esperanto, then this essay is useful for you. It is called Lingvoj en Filipinoj (Languages in the Philippines).

Recommended Resources

[ALMA] Almario, Virgilio S. UP Diksiyonaryong Filipino. Philippines: Anvil Publishing Inc., 2001.

[ATIE] Atienza, Monico M. Kilusang Pambansa-Demokratiko sa Wika. Lunsod Quezon, Pilipinas: UP Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, 1992.

[ENRI] Enriquez, Maria Rosario & M. Jacobo Enriquez. New Handy English Webster's Dictionary: English-Tagalog Tagalog-English. Philippines: Philippine Book Company, 1986.

Wish List

Amazon has many books. You can search for yourself using the key phrase 'Tagalog grammar'.

Learn Online

Tagalog Seasite is where comprehensive lessons about Tagalog are found. It is an award-winning site. In Christopher Sundita's Salit Blog, he explains Tagalog verbs with a historical perspective.

item.title: Another Egocentric Introspection: Spiritual Quest
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
B.E. = Thai Buddhist Era Year = Western Year + 543 years

I am growing up in the Philippines until age 10. I go to private school, La Salle, which is a Roman Catholic institution. I learn to pray with the rosary, to say "Hail Mary," and to do all the superficial things about the faith. But as I am young, it does not go deeper than that.

When I am ten years old, my family and I move to Canada. Soon, my parents are exposed to expatriate Filipinos who have converted to Protestant faiths, typically Baptist. My parents convert to Baptists when I am in high school. Soon, there is pressure to conform. As I am a "good boy" at this time, I go to Protestant church along with them. But none of the lectures inspire me. The whole Christian doctrine of an anthropomorphic, personal god seems alien to me, or even unappealing. I have in my mind the idea that a god would not be human-like or person-like. I have also the idea that an all-powerful god would not have the egocentric need to be worshipped by its created beings, but to be admired would be another matter. In any case, at this time, my mentor is Mr. Spock, the logical, scientific mind. It is all mostly science in high school and throughout university. I would not be converted to Protestantism.

A turning point occurs sometime after university when I am stationed in Tky for working as a software engineer. I am exposed to the subtle Eastern ways. I have lots of opportunity to visit Shint shrines and Buddhist temples. I become more interested in Eastern philosophy.

I begin more study of Buddhism after I return home to Canada. The philosophy fits more with my lifestyle. I learn about the so-called Four Noble Truths, which center on the idea that [1] existence is full of suffering (dukkha), that [2] suffering comes from craving, that [3] suffering can end, and that [4] there is a methodology to end suffering. It seems like a realistic religion. I discover that, whilst Christianity is based on salvation from sin, Buddhism is based on salvation from suffering. It intrigues me. Dukkha has wide-ranging meaning; aside from suffering, it could also mean mild irritation, discontent, and things of that sort.

Buddhism also has the idea of anicca (impermanent); "all formations are impermanent" ("sabbe sankhr anicc" in Pali). It saddens us when our favourite appliance dies on us, a relationship ends, a pet passes away, a sweet old house goes for demolition, and so on. Such is the impermanence in life. Once I accept this doctrine, I become more healthily detached from things.

Another general Buddhist concept is snyat in Sanskrit or suat in Pali; it is the void and emptiness of all things. Nothing exists essentially. The Heart Sutra says, "Form is emptiness, emptiness is form."

Meanwhile, samsra is the opposite of nirvna. Samsra (literally "perpetual wandering") is the world we live now, the world of illusion, or possibly, the round of rebirths. In Buddhism, we seek to escape samsra to achieve the ultimate goal, the extinction of greed, hate, and delusion, and of attachment to existence; this goal is called nirvna in Sanskrit or nibbna in Pali. This attainment is one form of enlightenment. In the Zen sect of Buddhism, we hear also of another called satori in Japanese. It is a sudden, abrupt event achievable in our lifetime, something like the brightest idea we can have, but without the idea; it is really indescribable in words. Zen is really different from all other sects of Buddhism because it steers away from any logocentric ("word-centric") thinking.

Out of curiosity, I read up on Hinduism to compare with Buddhism. In polytheistic Hinduism, there is an all-encompassing god called Brahma, who is the Creator, part of the Trinity that includes Vishnu, the Preserver; and Shiva, the Destroyer. Strictly speaking, Buddhism in contrast acknowledges no Master God, personalized with human-like attributes: jealousy, forgiveness, kindness, anger, and the like. Buddhism admits that by itself it can never fully explain who or what (the) god(s) is/are and it never makes any attempts to do so. Buddhism is not theocentric.

In Hinduism, there is also the belief in tman, the Eternal Soul or Self, which is essentially the same as the omnipresent Ultimate Reality, Brahman (not to be confused with Brahma). Buddhism, on the other hand, has the belief in Antman, the Non-Self, Egolessness, or the Self as an Illusion. This central Buddhist doctrine, Antman in Sanskrit and Anatt in Pali, teaches that "neither within the bodily and mental phenomena, nor outside of them, can be found anything that in the ultimate sense could be regarded as a self-existing real ego-entity, soul or any other abiding substance" (Buddhist Dictionary by Nyanatiloka). Buddhists believe each of us has a never-ending "stream of consciousness," not really a soul.

Jainism, another Eastern religion, has what I think is the really excellent concept of Aneknta or Anekntavda (non-absolutism or many-pointedness), which means that no claims to absolute truth can be made; all truths depend on various perspectives and, therefore, all knowledge is partial. There is a classic traditional story about some blind men touching an elephant and trying to describe what it is. Each man gives a different description depending on what he touched: the trunk, side, tusk. All are valid, but none can define the whole elephant. This paradigm brings us back to the Hindu's tman (Eternal Self) and the Buddhist's Antman (Non-Self). The Jains argue that the view of the permanent self and the view of the impermanent self are different, but equally valid perspectives; both can be true simultaneously.

Then there is Daoism from China, the Philosophy of the Five Elements: [1] Water, [2] Fire, [3] Wood, [4] Metal, and [5] Earth; these are symbolized respectively by the colours Black/Blue, Red, Green/Blue, White, and Yellow. Daoism is what I term "a cute philosophy." I learn that the Dao is some kind of pervading force in the universe, present in all things; it balances the Yin (dark) and the Yang (bright). Neither is the Dao a Master God. Daoism also teaches the idea of wwi or 'non-doing', of not being reactive, of being more passive to psychosocial environmental forces, to "bend with the wind" and "not to struggle against the current." It is like The Beatles' "Let It Be."

Daoists also believe that each person has two types of souls, the seven Yin Souls, produced at conception, and the three Yang Souls, which join the Yin Souls at birth. When they are joined in harmonious union, life flourishes; when they separate, sickness or death occurs. There are several schools of Daoism. The Inner Deity Hygiene School believes that 36,000 deities (shn) inhabit the macrocosm and each human body. The shn are often contrasted with the gu, which are rogue demons, formed from Yin Soul components of dead people. Parenthetically, the Hindus of India believe that there is a divine grain within each human being.

The question of how much and what kind of divinity humans possess arises. In the Christian Bible, the assertion "You are gods" appears in Psalm 82:6 and John 10:34. Some interpretations say that this assertion refers to humans in general, or to some humans, or even to angels. The debate continues.

Adherents of the complex Ancient Egyptian polytheistic religion believe that a human is composed of the kha (the mortal body) and at least three subtle semi-divine elements, the ka (the double), the ba (the soul), and the akh (the spirit).

The polytheistic Inuit (Eskimos) believe that besides personal souls, and various ghosts and spirits that inhabit the Arctic tundra, there are also "name souls." A personal name has a soul of its own, a guardian spirit to the name-bearer. An Inuk can have many names.

The ancient Persian religion founded by the Prophet Zarathustra, Zoroastrianism, expounds on the dualism between Good and Evil. The spirit of destructive force, Angra Mainyu, opposes the spirit of creative force, Spenta Mainyu. The universe is a battleground between the two forces. Zoroastrians dedicate to the three-fold path: "Good thoughts, good words, good deeds."

Do I believe in rebirth or reincarnation? Or do I believe that when I die, it will be just silent, tranquil nothingness? Or will I be reborn into Sukhvat, the Realm of Bliss, which, the Pure Land Sect of Buddhism believes, leads to Enlightenment? On these things, I just say "I do not know" and leave it at that. On such things, I am an agnostic because no one can prove or disprove them. Nevertheless, things in nature do come in cycles, we can intuitively perceive. Also, there is hyperspace, which comprises "places" beyond our three-dimensional space. And beings are more than three-dimensional; one could say "n-dimensional." Death is not a total end.

In Mahyna Buddhism, there is the concept of the Dharmakya Buddha, the Reality Body, the Buddha-Mind, the One Mind. All things are just ripples, waves, evanescent bubbles, appearing in the ocean of this One Mind. In this worldview, life is just a bubble.

Am I vegetarian? No, I am not. Yes, I eat pork chops sometimes and the casual steak, although I prefer eating chicken and seafood. Whilst some vegetarians claim that eating meat is "bad karma" because of the killing of animals, I for one do not discriminate among animals, plants, and fungi. One pseudo-vegetarian friend said to me, "But a carrot has no Buddha-nature." Well, I think there is vital life force or energy in all things, perhaps even in rocks, a view shared by Native Indians, Japanese Shint worshippers, and even ancient Filipinos. In Shint, the energy spirits that inhabit everywhere in nature are called kami.

In 2545 B.E., I begin study of meditation at my neighbourhood Thai Buddhist temple, which teaches the Theravda tradition. It really opens doors for me. I learn that meditation empowers the mind to overcome the forces of malevolent spirits. The kinds of meditation that I study are called samdhi (concentration) or samatha (tranquility) meditation, and vipassan (insight) meditation. Going to that temple is the first time I actually become socially engaged in the dharma, the Buddhist teachings.

By the end of 2547 B.E., I start to take a little interest in monotheistic Abrahamic religions, which include Islam, Bah' Faith, Christianity, Judaism, and Sikhism. For $6, I buy A Basic Jewish Encyclopedia and find some remarkable insights. I discover the touchy subject that Jews believe that everyone is born without sin and that no one is under the bondage of sin, and they do not believe in "original sin" as the Christians do. The encyclopedia states that "learning is the badge of the Jew; his cry is for justice; his zeal is for truth; and his mark (the sign by which he is recognized) is mercy and compassion." Contrary to popular belief, there are many converts to Judaism; a convert is called a ger.

What I find extraordinary in the Bah' Faith is the declaration by the Prophet Bah'u'llh that to achieve the Most Great Peace, the nations of the world ought to adopt an International Auxiliary Language, whether it be natural or constructed, and to teach it "to the children in all the schools of the world, that the world may become even one land and one home" as mentioned in the Tablet of Ishrqt. It is certainly a sage idea.

Unflinchingly, I can say that my concept of god or gods is different from most organized religions. I think that god is or gods are beyond gender: male, female, or neuter. And it is or they are beyond number: from zero to infinity. Gender and number are human limitations. My mind is open to the idea that there could be a hierarchy of higher intelligences above the human level, but whether to call them "gods" is up to the believer. One can be an atheist and Buddhist simultaneously, or a theist and a Buddhist simultaneously.

Nowadays, I do not wish to be boxed and labelled "Buddhist," but if someone asks what my religion is, I just say that I am an eclectic of various Eastern philosophies. I do believe in my individuation of the dharma. This individuation emphasizes personal authority through freeing myself from the constraints of collectively held beliefs. My exposure to a wide range of Buddhist traditions, like Zen, Pure Land, and Theravda, empower me to create my own distinctive track of dharma practice. I have also read the Bhavagad-Gta, a Hindu sacred book, from a Hare Krishna perspective, and I like the teachings.

Part of my spiritual quest has been refining my family history, my genealogy. Part of who I am is my genes. In traditional anthropology, I would be a multiracial mixture of Mongoloid, Caucasoid, and Australoid races. Mongoloid is from Han Chinese. Caucasoid is from Spanish, Greek, Jew, and Portuguese. I am also partly indigenous Filipino. Filipino Natives, as the vast majority of South-East Asians, themselves are an ancient mixture of Mongoloid and Australoid. My ancestors travelled very far and wide through the eons.

What have I really learned through all this spiritual research? Well, there is a lot. One important thing is that life is so personally meaningful, yet utterly meaningless at the same time. There are two sides of a coin. We live on a speck of dust in a universe so unimaginably vast and ever-changing. In that context, life is utterly meaningless. But we, as temporary ego-aggregates, ascribe our own meaning to life. Life is meaningless and meaningful. Our human language struggles to characterize what life really is.

Life as a right-brain-dominant person, which I suspect I am, is less time-oriented and is more spatially oriented than that of left-brain-dominant people, the majority. For me, time is like a rubber band, as it stretches and shrinks.

In the spring of 2548 B.E., I encounter a curious and novel philosophy called Singularitarianism, a belief in a coming event in history, the Singularity, when technology creates smarter-than-human intelligence. From then, it is the Snowball Effect on human and transhuman development for a better world, the Singularitarians believe.

All in all, I am an alienist. I believe that my god is an alien.

 

Copyright 2546-2550 B.E. by Victor Medrano

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Bonjour tous!

I've been working on Bonjang...

I describe it as "a language that evokes images of bamboo groves, misty mountain escarpments, and ancient temples. It is the language of the magical halflings of the Eastern Isles. It is a highly regular language with elegant simplicity."

The grammar is simple. Endings tell which part of speech a word is.

-ng nouns
-m adjectives, ordinal numbers
-n adverbs
_ verbs, particles, cardinal numbers

Example: piha (to be beautiful), pihang (beauty), piham (beautiful),
pihan (beautifully)

See and hear more of Bonjang at:

http://purl.oclc.org/net/bonjang

--Viktoro

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I read some interesting news...

Hunters Claim to Find 4-Winged Dinosaur
(AP) - Fossil hunters in China have discovered what may be one of the weirdest prehistoric species ever seen a four-winged dinosaur that apparently glided from tree to tree. The 128-million-year-old animal called Microraptor gui, in honor of Chinese paleontologist Gu Zhiwei was about 2 1/2 feet long and had two sets of feathered wings, with one set on its forelimbs and the other on its hind legs. Exactly where the creature fits into the evolution of birds and dinosaurs is not clear.

item.content:encoded: Tonight, it's foggy and misty outside.  And the full moon is out.  It's hauntingly delicious...  I love walking in the fog.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Bluish

I created a new language called Bluish.  Click here!

<<  Bluish, or the Bluetongue (vlOk'Zik), is the language spoken in the surreal Blueland (vlOk'grap), where blue is a sacred colour, the colour of the sea and sky. Bluish is abstract art. The inspiration comes from various sources, but mainly Thai, Cantonese, Tagalog, and Klingon. You can see the influence of Thai in the selection of initial consonant clusters. You can see the influence of Cantonese in the selection of final consonants. You can see the influence of Tagalog in the "focus" or "trigger" system of grammar. You can see the influence of Klingon in the use of uppercase and lowercase letters to differentiate phonemes and in the agglutinative nature of the grammar. It is all for "serious fun" as I always like to put it... >>

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
rad concept!

thanks for stopping by my humble site.

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
I love this song...

Artist : Byrds
Song : Turn! Turn! Turn!

To everything, turn, turn, turn.
There is a season, turn, turn, turn.
And a time to every purpose under heaven.
A time to be born, a time to die.
A time to plant, a time to reap.
A time to kill, a time to heal.
A time to laugh, a time to weep.

To everything, turn, turn, turn.
There is a season, turn, turn, turn.
And a time to every purpose under heaven.
A time to build up, a time to break down.
A time to dance, a time to mourn.
A time to cast away stones.
A time to gather stones together.

To everything, turn, turn, turn.
There is a season, turn, turn, turn.
And a time to every purpose under heaven.
A time of love, a time of hate.
A time of war, a time of peace.
A time you may embrace.
A time to refrain from embracing.

To everything, turn, turn, turn.
There is a season, turn, turn, turn.
And a time to every purpose under heaven.
A time to gain, a time to lose.
A time to rend, a time to sow.
A time for love, a time for hate.
A time for peace, I swear it's not too late.

item.content:encoded:
A Chat with My Friend

Viktoro says:

are you there?

Don says:

Yo! Wassup Homeboy?

Viktoro says:

watcha doin'?

Viktoro says:

oh ok

Viktoro says:

scifi?

Viktoro says:

drama?

Oh. it's just fantastik!

Don says:

Who's your favorite Actor(s) Actress(es) on movies beside what's her face...

Don says:

Cruz...

Viktoro says:

I like Vincent Price, Sharon Stone

Don says:

I need to find out who Vincent Price is, and what he look like... give me a sec

Viktoro says:

He's into the horror flics.

Don says:

Like what movie?

Viktoro says:

Old movies 60's, 70's

Don says:

Ohhh... I was barely born...

Viktoro says:

But his movies are classic...

Viktoro says:

Kind of gothic.

Viktoro says:

Did you find him on the web?

Don says:

I saw his photo, but I do not recognize any movie names... Is Sean Conery his era of actors too?

Viktoro says:

I think so.

Viktoro says:

Vincent has a cool accent.

Viktoro says:

Like some baron or count...

Viktoro says:

Like a vampire...

Don says:

I guess he's not as famous as Sean for me to notice him...

Viktoro says:

Well, he is famous...

Don says:

What is the last movie that he starred in, not as a supporting actor...

Don says:

?

Viktoro says:

I don't know the titles.

Don says:

The last movie he was in that was semi famous was Edward Scissorhands starring Johnny Depp and Wyona Rider...

Don says:

He was the inventor in the movie...

Viktoro says:

Oh, yeah!

Viktoro says:

1990's too.

Don says:

So what era was it when he was at his peak???

Don says:

Wow he was doing films since 1951...

Viktoro says:

1961 "the Pit and the Pendulum"

Don says:

So you are into old stuff?

Viktoro says:

I liked that movie.

Viktoro says:

Old, new. What's the difference?

Don says:

No difference, just a preference...

Viktoro says:

I like old and new.

Don says:

I am less of a retro guy, I am into modern or even futuristic movies...

Viktoro says:

Have heard of a 1965 film "Incubus" with William Shatner?

Don says:

Although if you are looking for plain drama, and not actions, or special effects, but more say like dialogs, then old and new don't matter that much.

Don says:

NO

Viktoro says:

The whole movie is in Esperanto... Would you believe it?

Don says:

NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!

Viktoro says:

YEAH!

Viktoro says:

You can hear Shatner speak Esperanto at http://www.incubusthefilm.com

Don says:

Like you sometimes, I am quite into the texture stuff in movies, and very particular about it.... for example, sound quality, image quality, beside acting and dialog, and background and settings does matter...

Don says:

If the set is lousy, it matters

Viktoro says:

yeah

Viktoro says:

My brother gave me _Minority Report_ for Christmas...

Don says:

So what Steven Spilberg and Industrial Light and Magic does for the movie industry is overwhelmingly important to me...

Viktoro says:

I thought _The Two Towers_ was a breakthrough...

Don says:

How does your brother knows you like Minority Report with Tom Cruise...

Don says:

?

Viktoro says:

Because we talked about it.

Don says:

2 towers was a breakthrough in what aspect?

Viktoro says:

Gollum.

Don says:

I see, its like you tell everyone what you want for Christmas, and they just go get it?

Don says:

Can they already do that in the Bugs Life?

Viktoro says:

No, we just casually talked about it. I didn't tell him that I wanted it...

Viktoro says:

I just watched in French! Cool!

Don says:

I just listened to the Shatner Esperanto sound track in Real Audio, it sounded like an Alien language...

Viktoro says:

He he

Don says:

On Planet Esparanta...

Viktoro says:

I want to buy the DVD one of these days...

Don says:

Do you understand the soundtrack?

Viktoro says:

His accent is a little funny.

Viktoro says:

But I understand it.

Don says:

ok... I have go do some tax work now for my father's company... work work work... I've been dreading it... but must get it done during the holiday.

Viktoro says:

OK. Hasta la vista!

Don says:

So long to you too...

item.content:encoded: An Indian fellow, a friend, at my evening meditation class at my neighbourhood Thai Buddhist temple, gave me his old book about learning Hindi called Universal Self Hindi Teacher.  I was thinking of buying a book just before.  Now, this saves me some bucks.  I am thinking of going to India one day...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
One of my friends stayed in India for 3 or 4 months travelling from place to place. Looked like quite an adventure from the photographs and stories he told.

Unlike our countries, mental illness is not hidden from the streets, and you will find extreme poverty, illness as well as extreme wealth.
Also if you like saving 'bucks', itis a very, very cheap place to visit!

item.title: Auroville
item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Interesting psychedelic town in India, called Auroville...  I wish there were more such visionary and idealistic towns in the world...

Auroville

Below was quoted from:

http://www.miraura.org/aa/av/av.html

"Planned as an international experimental township, Auroville was inspired by the evolutionary vision of Sri Aurobindo and founded by Mirra Alfassa, known as the Mother.

"Auroville was inaugurated on February 28, 1968 in a ceremony attended by representatives from 124 nations and all the states of India. In a gesture symbolic of human unity, a boy and a girl from each nation and state poured a handful of soil from their homeland into a lotus-shaped marble urn near the center of the city-to-be.

"Auroville has been endorsed by three resolutions of the UNESCO general assembly and recognized as an international trust by a unique Parliamentary Act of the Indian Government.

"Auroville welcomes people from all parts of the world to live together and explore cultural, educational, scientific, spiritual, and other pursuits in accordance with the Auroville Charter."

Auroville Charter

Below was quoted from:

http://www.miraura.org/aa/av/av-charter.html

  1. "Auroville belongs to nobody in particular. Auroville belongs to humanity as a whole. But to live in Auroville one must be the willing servitor of the Divine consciousness.

  2. "Auroville will be the place of an unending education, of constant progress, and a youth that never ages.
  3. "Auroville wants to be the bridge between the past and the future. Taking advantage of all discoveries from without and from within, Auroville will boldly spring towards future realizations.
  4. "Auroville will be a site of material and spiritual researches for a living embodiment of an actual human unity."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Utopia cannot just be "planned", it must be housed, peopled, and provided for by people who are congnizant of its goal. Then again, the human condition is so sexual it can hardly be described as perfect! How many live there now? Any second generation?

winniezpoo:

You can check the Auroville census at http://www.auroville.org/society/av_population.htm

item.dc:creator: viktoro

A Few Words in Slovio

"Lubim vodaju sportis. Ktor sport lubisx?"

This means:  "I like water sports.  Which sports do you like?"

I discovered this constructed Pan-Slavic language, Slovio, a couple of days ago.  Neat idea!  Poles, Russians, Czechs, and other Slavs can get together and speak this easy common language.

http://www.slovio.com

item.dc:creator: viktoro
item.content:encoded:
Mantra

In my meditation class, students are told to recite a word or phrase silently in the mind during meditation.  I know my friend F uses 'Om'.  The teacher suggests 'buddho' (Pali for "pure and awakened").  I started out with the word 'lojban', which means "logical language" in Lojban.  I like Lojban because it is a neutral language to me without the excess cultural baggage of natural languages.  After a while, I tried 'zasti', which means "exist" in Lojban.  Now I'm using 'tcati' (pronounced "CHAH-tee").  It means "tea" in Lojban.  I like the sound of it, the calming connotation, and the simplicity.  Meditation is like drinking tea.  So I like it so far:  "tcati, tcati, tcati, tcati,..."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
That's cool that you're using different linguistic elements in your meditation. I guess with 'tchati' you've found the right stimulus to get you into a deep sense of feeling whole?

Maybe I'll have to try that.

To damienponech:

Yeah, I have this feeling of being whole with 'tcati' (tea).  It seems like a humble word too.  I was thinking I might also use 'munje' (universe) one time, but it seems rather grandiose.
There is an CD/tape by Robert Gass called Om Nama Shiva..it is incredible to meditate to!
